The **2018 Winter Olympics** , officially known as the **XXIII Olympic Winter
Games** ([Korean](/wiki/Korean_language "Korean language"): 제23회 동계 올림픽,
[translit.](/wiki/Romanization_of_Korean "Romanization of Korean")
_Jeisipsamhoe Donggye Ollimpik_) and commonly known as **PyeongChang 2018** ,
was a major [multi-sport event](/wiki/Multi-sport_event "Multi-sport event")
held between 9 and 25 February 2018 in [Pyeongchang
County](/wiki/Pyeongchang_County "Pyeongchang County"), [Gangwon
Province](/wiki/Gangwon_Province,_South_Korea "Gangwon Province, South
Korea"), [South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea "South Korea"), with the opening
rounds for certain events held on 8 February 2018, the eve of the [opening
ceremony](/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics_opening_ceremony "2018 Winter Olympics
opening ceremony"). Pyeongchang was elected as the host city in July 2011,
during the [123rd IOC Session](/wiki/123rd_IOC_Session "123rd IOC Session") in
[Durban](/wiki/Durban "Durban"), [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South
Africa"). This marks the first time South Korea has hosted the [Winter
Olympics](/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games "Winter Olympic Games"), and the second
time the Olympic games have been held in the country, after the [1988 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics "1988 Summer Olympics") in
[Seoul](/wiki/Seoul "Seoul"). It also marks the third time [East
Asia](/wiki/East_Asia "East Asia") has hosted the Winter Games, after
[Sapporo](/wiki/Sapporo "Sapporo"), [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan")
([1972](/wiki/1972_Winter_Olympics "1972 Winter Olympics")), and
[Nagano](/wiki/Nagano,_Nagano "Nagano, Nagano"), Japan
([1998](/wiki/1998_Winter_Olympics "1998 Winter Olympics")), and the sixth
overall Olympic Games held in East Asia. It was the first of three consecutive
Olympic Games to be held in East Asia, preceding [Tokyo
2020](/wiki/2020_Summer_Olympics "2020 Summer Olympics") (Summer) and [Beijing
2022](/wiki/2022_Winter_Olympics "2022 Winter Olympics") (Winter).

The games featured 102 events in fifteen sports, with the addition of ["big
air" snowboarding](/wiki/Snowboarding#Big_air "Snowboarding"), [mass
start](/wiki/Mass_start "Mass start") [speed skating](/wiki/Speed_skating
"Speed skating"), [mixed doubles curling](/wiki/Mixed_doubles_curling "Mixed
doubles curling"), and mixed team [alpine skiing](/wiki/Alpine_skiing "Alpine
skiing") to the Winter Olympic programme. 2,914 athletes from 92
[NOCs](/wiki/National_Olympic_Committee "National Olympic Committee")
competed, including the debuts of
[Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador_National_Olympic_Committee "Ecuador National Olympic
Committee"), [Eritrea](/wiki/Eritrea_National_Olympic_Committee "Eritrea
National Olympic Committee"), [Kosovo](/wiki/Kosovo_National_Olympic_Committee
"Kosovo National Olympic Committee"),
[Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia_National_Olympic_Committee "Malaysia National
Olympic Committee"), [Nigeria](/wiki/Nigeria_National_Olympic_Committee
"Nigeria National Olympic Committee") and
[Singapore](/wiki/Singapore_National_Olympic_Committee "Singapore National
Olympic Committee").

The lead-up to these Games was affected by the ongoing
[tensions](/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations "North Korea–South
Korea relations") between South Korea and [North Korea](/wiki/North_Korea
"North Korea"), and the [2017–18 missile
crisis](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_North_Korea_crisis "2017–18 North Korea
crisis"), which led to security concerns, with some countries threatening to
skip the games unless their safety was assured. In January 2018, after their
first high-level talks in over two years, North Korea agreed to
[participate](/wiki/North_Korea_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "North Korea at
the 2018 Winter Olympics") in the Games along with South Korea. The countries
also agreed to march together, as a united
"[Korea](/wiki/Korea_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "Korea at the 2018 Winter
Olympics")", during the opening ceremony, and to field a [unified women's ice
hockey team](/wiki/Korea_women%27s_national_ice_hockey_team "Korea women's
national ice hockey team").

## Bidding and
election[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Bidding and election")]

Main article: [Bids for the 2018 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/Bids_for_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "Bids for the 2018 Winter
Olympics")

[Pyeongchang](/wiki/Pyeongchang_County "Pyeongchang County") bid to host both
the [2010](/wiki/Bids_for_the_2010_Winter_Olympics "Bids for the 2010 Winter
Olympics") and [2014](/wiki/Bids_for_the_2014_Winter_Olympics "Bids for the
2014 Winter Olympics") Winter Olympics, but lost in the final rounds of voting
to [Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver") and [Sochi](/wiki/Sochi "Sochi")
respectively.[3]

[Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich") also launched a
[bid](/wiki/Munich_bid_for_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "Munich bid for the 2018
Winter Olympics") to host these Games. Prior to [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing
"Beijing")'s successful [2022 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2022_Winter_Olympics
"2022 Winter Olympics") [bid](/wiki/Beijing_bid_for_the_2022_Winter_Olympics
"Beijing bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics"), Munich would have become the
first city to host both the Winter and the Summer Games, having previously
hosted the [1972 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1972_Summer_Olympics "1972 Summer
Olympics"), but received only 25 votes. [Annecy](/wiki/Annecy "Annecy") (in
southeastern France) launched their own bid, which failed to secure public
support from the local citizens. Their bid ended up receiving seven votes.[4]

Pyeongchang was elected as the host city at the [123rd IOC
Session](/wiki/123rd_IOC_Session "123rd IOC Session") in [Durban](/wiki/Durban
"Durban") in 2011, earning the necessary majority of at least 48 votes in just
one round of voting, more votes than its competitors combined. With this,
Pyeongchang became the third Asian city to host the Winter Games; the first
two were in [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan"), at [Sapporo](/wiki/Sapporo
"Sapporo") ([1972](/wiki/1972_Winter_Olympics "1972 Winter Olympics")) and
[Nagano](/wiki/Nagano "Nagano") ([1998](/wiki/1998_Winter_Olympics "1998
Winter Olympics")).[5][6]

## Development and
preparation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Development and preparation")]

[![Pyeongchang is located in South
Korea](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/South_Korea_physical_map.svg/230px-
South_Korea_physical_map.svg.png)](/wiki/File:South_Korea_physical_map.svg
"Pyeongchang is located in South Korea")

![Pyeongchang](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/5px-
Red_pog.svg.png)

Pyeongchang

[](/wiki/File:South_Korea_physical_map.svg "File:South Korea physical
map.svg")

Location in [South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea "South Korea")

On 5 August 2011, the [International Olympic
Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic
Committee") (IOC) announced the formation of the Pyeongchang 2018 Coordination
Commission.[7][8] On 4 October 2011, it was announced that the Organizing
Committee for the 2018 Winter Olympics would be headed by [Kim Jin-
sun](/wiki/Kim_Jin-sun "Kim Jin-sun"). The [Pyeongchang Organizing Committee
for the 2018 Olympic & Paralympic Winter
Games](/wiki/Pyeongchang_Organizing_Committee_for_the_2018_Olympic_%26_Paralympic_Winter_Games
"Pyeongchang Organizing Committee for the 2018 Olympic & Paralympic Winter
Games") (POCOG) was launched at its inaugural assembly on 19 October 2011. The
first tasks of the organizing committee were putting together a master plan
for the games as well as forming a design for the venues.[9] The IOC
Coordination Commission for the 2018 Winter Olympics made their first visit to
Pyeongchang in March 2012. By then, construction was already underway on the
Olympic Village.[10][11] In June 2012, construction began on a high-speed rail
line that is to connect Pyeongchang to [Seoul](/wiki/Seoul "Seoul").[12]

The [International Paralympic
Committee](/wiki/International_Paralympic_Committee "International Paralympic
Committee") met for an orientation with the Pyeongchang 2018 organizing
committee in July 2012.[13] Then-IOC President [Jacques
Rogge](/wiki/Jacques_Rogge "Jacques Rogge") visited Pyeongchang for the first
time in February 2013.[14]

The Pyeongchang Organizing Committee for the 2018 Olympic & Paralympic Winter
Games created [Pyeongchang WINNERS](/wiki/Pyeongchang_WINNERS "Pyeongchang
WINNERS") in 2014 by recruiting university students living in South Korea to
spread awareness of the Olympic Games through [social networking
services](/wiki/Social_networking_services "Social networking services") and
news articles.[15]

###
Medals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Medals")]

The Games' medal designs were unveiled on 21 September 2017. Designed by Lee
Suk-woo, they feature a pattern of diagonal ridges on both sides, with the
front including the Olympic rings, and the obverse featuring the Games'
emblem, the event name and the discipline. The edge of the medals features
extrusions of [hangul](/wiki/Hangul "Hangul") alphabets, while the ribbons are
made from a traditional South Korean textile.[16]

### Torch
relay[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Torch relay")]

Main article: [2018 Winter Olympics torch
relay](/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics_torch_relay "2018 Winter Olympics torch
relay")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/2018_Winter_Olympic_%26_Paralympic_Torch%2CNMKCH.jpg/100px-2018_Winter_Olympic_%26_Paralympic_Torch%2CNMKCH.jpg)](/wiki/File:2018_Winter_Olympic_%26_Paralympic_Torch,NMKCH.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2018_Winter_Olympic_%26_Paralympic_Torch,NMKCH.jpg "Enlarge")

2018 Winter Olympics torch

The torch relay started on 24 October 2017 in Greece and ended at the start of
the Olympics on 9 February 2018. On 1 November 2017 the relay entered Korea.
The relay lasted 101 days. There were 7,500 torch bearers to represent the
Korean population of 75 million people. There were also 2,018 support runners
to guard the torch and act as messengers.

The torch and its bearers traveled by a diverse means of transportation,
including by [turtle ship](/wiki/Turtle_ship "Turtle ship") in Hansando
Island, sailboat on the [Baengmagang River](/wiki/Baengmagang_River
"Baengmagang River") in [Buyeo](/wiki/Buyeo_County "Buyeo County"), marine
cable car in [Yeosu](/wiki/Yeosu "Yeosu"), zip-wire over
[Bamseom](/wiki/Bamseom "Bamseom") Island, steam train in the
[Gokseong](/wiki/Gokseong "Gokseong") Train Village, marine rail bike along
the east coast in [Samcheok](/wiki/Samcheok "Samcheok"), and by yacht in
[Busan](/wiki/Busan "Busan") Metropolitan City.

There were also robot torch relays in [Jeju](/wiki/Jeju_City "Jeju City") and
[Daejeon](/wiki/Daejeon "Daejeon").[17]

The Olympic events were held in the county of
[Pyeongchang](/wiki/Pyeongchang_County "Pyeongchang County"), except for the
ice events, which take place in the neighboring city of
[Gangneung](/wiki/Gangneung "Gangneung"), and downhill, super-G and combined,
which take place in the neighboring county of
[Jeongseon](/wiki/Jeongseon_County "Jeongseon County").

#### Pyeongchang (mountain
cluster)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Pyeongchang \(mountain cluster\)")]

##### Alpensia Sports
Park[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Alpensia Sports Park")]

The [Alpensia Resort](/wiki/Alpensia_Resort "Alpensia Resort") in
[Daegwallyeong-myeon](/wiki/Daegwallyeong-myeon "Daegwallyeong-myeon"),
Pyeongchang, was the focus of the 2018 Winter Olympics.[18][19]

  * [Pyeongchang Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Pyeongchang_Olympic_Stadium "Pyeongchang Olympic Stadium") – opening and closing ceremonies[20]
  * [Alpensia Ski Jumping Centre](/wiki/Alpensia_Ski_Jumping_Stadium "Alpensia Ski Jumping Stadium") – ski jumping, Nordic combined, snowboarding (big air)
  * [Alpensia Biathlon Centre](/wiki/Alpensia_Biathlon_Centre "Alpensia Biathlon Centre") – biathlon
  * [Alpensia Cross-Country Centre](/wiki/Alpensia_Cross-Country_Centre "Alpensia Cross-Country Centre") – cross-country skiing, Nordic combined
  * [Alpensia Sliding Centre](/wiki/Alpensia_Sliding_Centre "Alpensia Sliding Centre") – luge, bobsleigh, and skeleton
  * Olympic Village
  * [Yongpyong Alpine Centre](/wiki/Yongpyong_Ski_Resort "Yongpyong Ski Resort") – alpine skiing (slalom, giant slalom)

#### Stand-alone
venues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Stand-alone venues")]

  * [Bogwang Phoenix Park](/wiki/Bogwang_Phoenix_Park "Bogwang Phoenix Park") in [Bongpyeong-myeon](/wiki/Bongpyeong-myeon "Bongpyeong-myeon"), Pyeongchang – freestyle skiing and snowboard
  * [Jeongseon Alpine Centre](/wiki/Jeongseon_Alpine_Centre "Jeongseon Alpine Centre") in Pyeongchang's neighboring county of [Jeongseon](/wiki/Jeongseon_County "Jeongseon County") – alpine skiing (downhill, super-G and combined)

#### Gangneung (coastal
cluster)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Gangneung \(coastal cluster\)")]

The coastal cluster is located in Pyeongchang's neighboring city of
[Gangneung](/wiki/Gangneung "Gangneung"). The [Gangneung Olympic
Park](/wiki/Gangneung_Olympic_Park "Gangneung Olympic Park") includes the
following four venues:

  * [Gangneung Hockey Centre](/wiki/Gangneung_Hockey_Centre "Gangneung Hockey Centre") – ice hockey (men's competition)
  * [Gangneung Curling Centre](/wiki/Gangneung_Curling_Centre "Gangneung Curling Centre") – curling
  * [Gangneung Oval](/wiki/Gangneung_Oval "Gangneung Oval")[20] – speed skating
  * [Gangneung Ice Arena](/wiki/Gangneung_Ice_Arena "Gangneung Ice Arena") – short track speed skating and figure skating

In addition, a stand-alone venue is located on the grounds of [Catholic
Kwandong University](/wiki/Catholic_Kwandong_University "Catholic Kwandong
University"):

  * [Kwandong Hockey Centre](/wiki/Kwandong_Hockey_Centre "Kwandong Hockey Centre") – ice hockey (women's competition)

###
Ticketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Ticketing")]

Ticket prices for the 2018 Winter Olympics were announced in April 2016 and
tickets went on sale in October 2016. Event tickets ranged in price from
[₩](/wiki/South_Korean_won "South Korean won")20,000 (approx. [US$](/wiki/USD
"USD")17) to ₩900,000 (~US$776) while tickets for the opening and closing
ceremonies ranged from ₩220,000 (~US$190) to ₩1.5 million (~US$1293). The
exact prices were determined through market research; around 50% of the
tickets were expected to cost about ₩80,000 (~US$69) or less, and tickets in
sports that are relatively unknown in the region, such as biathlon and luge,
were made cheaper in order to encourage attendance. By contrast, figure
skating and the men's ice hockey gold-medal game carried the most expensive
tickets of the Games.[21]

As of 11 October 2017, domestic ticket sales for the Games were reported to be
slow. Of the 750,000 seats allocated to South Koreans, only 20.7% had been
sold. International sales were more favorable, with 59.7% of the 320,000
allocated tickets sold.[22][23] However, as of 31 January 2018, 77% of all
tickets had been sold.[24]

## The
Games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: The Games")]

### Opening
ceremony[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Opening ceremony")]

Main article: [2018 Winter Olympics opening
ceremony](/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics_opening_ceremony "2018 Winter Olympics
opening ceremony")

The [opening ceremony](/wiki/Opening_ceremony "Opening ceremony") of the 2018
Winter Olympics was held at the [Pyeongchang Olympic
Stadium](/wiki/Pyeongchang_Olympic_Stadium "Pyeongchang Olympic Stadium") on 9
February 2018; the US$100 million facility was only intended to be used for
the opening and closing ceremonies of these Olympics and the subsequent
[Paralympics](/wiki/2018_Winter_Paralympics "2018 Winter Paralympics"), and is
scheduled to be demolished following their conclusion.[25]

###
Sports[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Sports")]

The 2018 Winter Olympics featured 102 events in 15 sports,[26] making it the
first Winter Olympics to surpass 100 medal events. Six new events in existing
sports were introduced to the Winter Olympic program in Pyeongchang, including
men's and ladies' [big air](/wiki/Snowboarding#Big_air "Snowboarding")
snowboarding, [mixed doubles curling](/wiki/Mixed_doubles_curling "Mixed
doubles curling"), men's and ladies' mass start speed skating, and mixed team
alpine skiing.[27][26]

sport._

For the first time since 1998, the [National Hockey
League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") did not provide
accommodations (including a break in the season for all teams during the
Olympics) to allow its players to participate in the men's ice hockey
tournament. The NHL's decision stemmed from their demands that the IOC cover
the cost of insuring the NHL players who participated in the Games. Although
the IOC did pay to insure NHL players in Sochi, the commission was unwilling
to do so for Pyeongchang, and was concerned that the NHL's demand could set a
precedent for other professional sports bodies to follow. NHL Commissioner
[Gary Bettman](/wiki/Gary_Bettman "Gary Bettman") added that a factor in the
decision was that the IOC did not allow the NHL to promote the involvement of
its players in the Olympics.[28][29][30] The NHL secured the cooperation of
the [International Ice Hockey
Federation](/wiki/International_Ice_Hockey_Federation "International Ice
Hockey Federation") and the IOC, who agreed to establish a
[blacklist](/wiki/Blacklisting "Blacklisting") forbidding national teams from
nominating or accepting players under NHL contract to their Olympic
rosters.[31][32]

### Participating National Olympic
Committees[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Participating National Olympic Committees")]

A total of 92 teams qualified at least one athlete to compete in the Games.
Six nations made their Winter Olympics debut: Ecuador, Eritrea, Kosovo,
Malaysia, Nigeria and Singapore.[33][34] Athletes from three further countries
– the Cayman Islands, Dominica and Peru – qualified to compete, but all three
National Olympic Committees returned the quota spots back to the
[International Ski Federation](/wiki/International_Ski_Federation
"International Ski Federation") (FIS).[35]

Under an historic agreement facilitated by the IOC, qualified athletes from
[North Korea](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea") were allowed to cross the
[Korean Demilitarized Zone](/wiki/Korean_Demilitarized_Zone "Korean
Demilitarized Zone") into South Korea to compete in the Games.[36][37][38] The
two nations marched together under the [Korean Unification
Flag](/wiki/Korean_Unification_Flag "Korean Unification Flag") during the
opening ceremony.[39][40] A [unified Korean
team](/wiki/Korea_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "Korea at the 2018 Winter
Olympics"), consisting of 12 players from North Korea and 23 from South Korea,
competed in the [women's ice hockey
tournament](/wiki/Ice_hockey_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_tournament
"Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament") under a special
IOC country code designation (COR) following talks in
[Panmunjom](/wiki/Panmunjom "Panmunjom") on 17 January 2018.[41] The two
nations also participated separately: the [South Korea
team](/wiki/South_Korea_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "South Korea at the 2018
Winter Olympics") competed in every sport and the [North Korea
team](/wiki/North_Korea_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "North Korea at the 2018
Winter Olympics") competed in alpine skiing, cross-country skiing, figure
skating and short track speed skating.[42] See [North Korea at the 2018 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/North_Korea_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "North Korea at the
2018 Winter Olympics") for further details.

On 5 December 2017, the IOC announced that the [Russian Olympic
Committee](/wiki/Russian_Olympic_Committee "Russian Olympic Committee") had
been suspended due to the Russian doping controversy and the investigation
into the [2014 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics "2014 Winter
Olympics") in Sochi. Individual Russian athletes, who qualified and could
demonstrate they had complied with the IOC's doping regulations, were given
the option to compete at the 2018 games as "[Olympic Athletes from
Russia](/wiki/Olympic_Athletes_from_Russia_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics
"Olympic Athletes from Russia at the 2018 Winter Olympics")" (OAR) under the
[Olympic flag](/wiki/Olympic_flag "Olympic flag") and with the [Olympic
anthem](/wiki/Olympic_Hymn "Olympic Hymn") played at any ceremony.[43]

### Event
scheduling[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Event scheduling")]

To accommodate primetime broadcasts in the Americas, [figure
skating](/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "Figure skating at
the 2018 Winter Olympics") events were scheduled with morning start times;
figure skating in particular has typically been one of the most popular Winter
Olympic events among American/Latin American viewers. This scheduling practice
has had an impact on the events themselves, including skaters having to adjust
to the modified schedule, as well as the attendance levels of the sessions
themselves.[50]

Controversially, eight of the eleven biathlon events were scheduled at night,
making it necessary for biathletes to compete under difficult conditions for
those events, such as skiing and shooting under floodlights, colder
temperatures, and blustery winds.[51]

###
Records[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Records")]

Main article: [World and Olympic records set at the 2018 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/World_and_Olympic_records_set_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics
"World and Olympic records set at the 2018 Winter Olympics")

  * On 8 February, the day before the opening of the Games, [Noriaki Kasai](/wiki/Noriaki_Kasai "Noriaki Kasai") of Japan took part in the ski jumping qualification. In doing so he became the first athlete in history to participate in eight Winter Olympics.[56] The record was previously held by the Russian luger [Albert Demchenko](/wiki/Albert_Demchenko "Albert Demchenko"), who had participated seven times.
  * On 11 February, Dutch speed skater [Sven Kramer](/wiki/Sven_Kramer "Sven Kramer") won a gold medal in the men's 5000m event, making him the only male speed skater to win the same Olympic event [three times](/wiki/List_of_multiple_Olympic_gold_medalists_in_one_event "List of multiple Olympic gold medalists in one event"). He also became the first man to win a total of [eight Olympic medals](/wiki/List_of_multiple_Olympic_medalists "List of multiple Olympic medalists") in speed skating.[57]
  * On 12 February, [Ireen Wüst](/wiki/Ireen_W%C3%BCst "Ireen Wüst") of the Netherlands became the first speed skater, male or female, to win [ten Winter Olympic medals](/wiki/List_of_multiple_Winter_Olympic_medallists "List of multiple Winter Olympic medallists") and the first female Winter Olympian to win [nine individual medals](/wiki/List_of_multiple_Olympic_medalists#List_of_most_career_medals_in_individual_events "List of multiple Olympic medalists"). She also won an individual gold medal for the fourth Olympics in a row, the first time this was achieved by a Winter Olympian.[58]
  * On 14 February, Dutch athlete [Jorien ter Mors](/wiki/Jorien_ter_Mors "Jorien ter Mors") won a speed skating gold medal in the [1000 meters](/wiki/Speed_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_1000_metres "Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 1000 metres"); on 20 February, she was part of the Dutch short track team that won the bronze in the [3000 metre relay](/wiki/Short_track_speed_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_3000_metre_relay "Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 3000 metre relay"). In doing so, she became the first female athlete to win Olympic medals in [two different sports at a single Winter Games](/wiki/List_of_athletes_with_Olympic_medals_in_different_disciplines "List of athletes with Olympic medals in different disciplines").[59]
  * On 15 February, German figure skaters [Aliona Savchenko](/wiki/Aliona_Savchenko "Aliona Savchenko") and [Bruno Massot](/wiki/Bruno_Massot "Bruno Massot") set a new [ISU best free skating score](/wiki/List_of_highest_scores_in_figure_skating#Seniors "List of highest scores in figure skating") of 159.31 in [pair skating](/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Pairs_skating "Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Pairs skating").[60]
  * On 16 February, American [Nathan Chen](/wiki/Nathan_Chen "Nathan Chen") became the first figure skater to land five [quadruple jumps](/wiki/Quadruple_jump "Quadruple jump") in one program.[61]
  * On 19 February, Germany and Canada tied for gold in the two-man bobsleigh event. This was only the [second time in history](/wiki/List_of_ties_for_medals_at_the_Olympics "List of ties for medals at the Olympics") that two countries had tied for a gold medal in this particular event, the first time being in the [1998 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1998_Winter_Olympics "1998 Winter Olympics") twenty years earlier.[62]
  * On 19 February, Canadian figure skaters [Tessa Virtue](/wiki/Tessa_Virtue "Tessa Virtue") and [Scott Moir](/wiki/Scott_Moir "Scott Moir") set a new [ISU best short dance score](/wiki/List_of_highest_scores_in_figure_skating#Seniors "List of highest scores in figure skating") of 83.67 in [ice dance](/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Ice_dancing "Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Ice dancing")[63] and they set a new [ISU best combined total score](/wiki/List_of_highest_scores_in_figure_skating#Seniors "List of highest scores in figure skating") of 206.07 on 20 February.[64] That same day, [Gabriella Papadakis](/wiki/Gabriella_Papadakis "Gabriella Papadakis") and [Guillaume Cizeron](/wiki/Guillaume_Cizeron "Guillaume Cizeron") set a new [ISU best free dance score](/wiki/List_of_highest_scores_in_figure_skating#Seniors "List of highest scores in figure skating") of 123.35 in [ice dance](/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Ice_dancing "Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Ice dancing").[65]
  * On 21 February, Norwegian cross-country skier [Marit Bjørgen](/wiki/Marit_Bj%C3%B8rgen "Marit Bjørgen") won a bronze medal in the [women's team sprint](/wiki/Cross-country_skiing_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_team_sprint "Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's team sprint"); this was her fourth medal at the 2018 Games and a record fourteenth Olympic medal, surpassing the previous record of fellow Norwegian athlete [Ole Einar Bjørndalen](/wiki/Ole_Einar_Bj%C3%B8rndalen "Ole Einar Bjørndalen") who holds a total of thirteen Olympic medals. Then on 25 February Bjørgen won a gold medal in the [30 kilometre classical event](/wiki/Cross-country_skiing_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_30_kilometre_classical "Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 30 kilometre classical"), bringing her total Olympic medal haul to fifteen, the [most won by any athlete](/wiki/List_of_multiple_Winter_Olympic_medallists "List of multiple Winter Olympic medallists") (male or female) in Winter Olympics history.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * On 22 February, Chinese short track speed skater [Wu Dajing](/wiki/Wu_Dajing "Wu Dajing") beat the world record twice en route to winning a gold medal in the [men's 500 metres](/wiki/Short_track_speed_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_500_metres "Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres") and became only the second person in history to have skated the discipline in less than 40 seconds (after American J. R. Celski), and the first person to achieve this at "sea level".[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * On 23 February, Russian figure skater [Alina Zagitova](/wiki/Alina_Zagitova "Alina Zagitova") set a new [ISU best short program score](/wiki/List_of_highest_scores_in_figure_skating#Seniors "List of highest scores in figure skating") of 82.92 in [Ladies' single skating](/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Ladies%27_singles "Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Ladies' singles").[66]
  * On 24 February, [Ester Ledecká](/wiki/Ester_Ledeck%C3%A1 "Ester Ledecká") of the Czech Republic became the first athlete ever to compete at the Winter Olympics in both [alpine skiing](/wiki/Alpine_skiing "Alpine skiing") and [snowboarding](/wiki/Snowboarding "Snowboarding"). On 17 February, she won a gold medal in the [skiing super-G](/wiki/Alpine_skiing_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_super-G "Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's super-G") event and one week later, on 24 February, she won a second gold medal in the [snowboarding parallel giant slalom](/wiki/Snowboarding_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_parallel_giant_slalom "Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's parallel giant slalom"). In so doing, she became the first female athlete to win Olympic gold medals in [two different sports at a single Winter Games](/wiki/List_of_athletes_with_Olympic_medals_in_different_disciplines "List of athletes with Olympic medals in different disciplines").[67]
  * On 24 February, Norway won a bronze medal in the [alpine skiing mixed team event](/wiki/Alpine_skiing_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Mixed_team "Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Mixed team"), their 38th medal at the 2018 Winter Olympics. In doing so, they set a new record for the highest number of medals won at a single Olympics. The USA team held the previous record, winning 37 medals in Vancouver in 2010.[68] By the end of the Games the Norwegian team had won one further medal, the gold won by Marit Bjørgen on 25 February, setting a new record of 39 Winter Olympic medals in a single Games.

### Closing
ceremony[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Closing ceremony")]

Main article: [2018 Winter Olympics closing
ceremony](/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics_closing_ceremony "2018 Winter Olympics
closing ceremony")

The [closing ceremony](/wiki/Closing_ceremony "Closing ceremony") of the 2018
Winter Olympics was held at the [Pyeongchang Olympic
Stadium](/wiki/Pyeongchang_Olympic_Stadium "Pyeongchang Olympic Stadium") on
25 February 2018, as [Thomas Bach](/wiki/Thomas_Bach "Thomas Bach"), the IOC
president, declared the Games closed, and the cauldron extinguished.

##
Broadcasting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Broadcasting")]

Main article: [List of 2018 Winter Olympics
broadcasters](/wiki/List_of_2018_Winter_Olympics_broadcasters "List of 2018
Winter Olympics broadcasters")

Broadcast rights to the 2018 Winter Olympics in some countries were already
sold as part of long-term broadcast rights deals, including the Games' local
rightsholder [SBS](/wiki/Seoul_Broadcasting_System "Seoul Broadcasting
System"), which in July 2011 had extended its rights to the Olympics through
to 2024.[69] SBS sub-licensed its rights to
[MBC](/wiki/Munhwa_Broadcasting_Corporation "Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation")
and [KBS](/wiki/Korean_Broadcasting_System "Korean Broadcasting System").[70]

On 29 June 2015, the IOC announced that [Discovery
Communications](/wiki/Discovery_Communications "Discovery Communications") had
acquired exclusive rights to the Olympics across all of Europe outside of
Russia, from 2018 through to 2024. Discovery's pan-European
[Eurosport](/wiki/Eurosport "Eurosport") networks were promoted as the main
rightsholder of the Games, but Discovery free-to-air channels such as
[DMAX](/wiki/DMAX_\(Spain\) "DMAX \(Spain\)") in Spain,[71] [Kanal
5](/wiki/Kanal_5_\(Sweden\) "Kanal 5 \(Sweden\)") in Sweden and
[TVNorge](/wiki/TVNorge "TVNorge") in Norway, were also involved.[72]
Discovery was required to sub-licence at least 100 hours of coverage to free-
to-air broadcasters in each market;[73][74][75] some of these agreements
required certain sports to be exclusive to Eurosport and its affiliated
networks.[76][76] The deal did not initially cover France due to [France
Télévisions](/wiki/France_T%C3%A9l%C3%A9visions "France Télévisions")' rights,
which run through to the 2020 Games.[77] In the United Kingdom, Discovery held
exclusive pay television rights under license from the [BBC](/wiki/BBC_Sport
"BBC Sport"), in return for BBC sub-licencing the free-to-air rights to the
2022 and 2024 Olympics from Discovery.[78]

Despite the Russian team being formally banned from competing under its flag
in Pyeongchang, Russian state broadcaster [Channel
One](/wiki/Channel_One_Russia "Channel One Russia"), and sports channel [Match
TV](/wiki/Match_TV "Match TV"), still committed to covering the Games with a
focus on Russian athletes.[77] Russia was not affected by the Eurosport deal,
due to a pre-existing contract held by a marketing agency which runs through
to 2024.[77]

In the United States, the Games once again were broadcast by [NBCUniversal
properties](/wiki/NBC_Olympic_broadcasts "NBC Olympic broadcasts") under a
long-term contract; it was NBC's first Olympics without long-time primary host
[Bob Costas](/wiki/Bob_Costas "Bob Costas"), who announced on 7 February 2017
his retirement from the role in favour of [Mike Tirico](/wiki/Mike_Tirico
"Mike Tirico").[79][80] On 28 March 2017, NBC also said that it would air most
primetime coverage simultaneously in all time zones in the United States, and
not broadcast on a [tape delay](/wiki/Broadcast_delay "Broadcast delay") as
they had in past Olympics (although as per prior practice, the ceremonies were
still delayed to primetime for the U.S. audience, but the network did reverse
its previous practice of not streaming the opening ceremony live online). U.S.
[Eastern Time](/wiki/Eastern_Time_Zone "Eastern Time Zone") is 14 hours behind
Pyeongchang, which allows certain events to be broadcast live in the U.S.
[primetime](/wiki/Primetime "Primetime") hours.[81][82]

[NHK](/wiki/NHK "NHK") and [Olympic Broadcasting
Services](/wiki/Olympic_Broadcasting_Services "Olympic Broadcasting Services")
once again filmed portions of the Games, including 90 hours of footage of
selected events and the opening ceremonies, in [high-dynamic-
range](/wiki/High-dynamic-range_video "High-dynamic-range video") [8K
resolution](/wiki/8K_resolution "8K resolution") video.[83][84] In South
Korea, [ATSC 3.0](/wiki/ATSC_3.0 "ATSC 3.0") terrestrial broadcasts at [4K
resolution](/wiki/4K_resolution "4K resolution") were introduced in 2017 in
time for the Olympics.[85][86] In the U.S., this footage is being delivered in
4K by NBCUniversal parent [Comcast](/wiki/Comcast "Comcast") to participating
television providers, including its own [Xfinity](/wiki/Xfinity "Xfinity") and
some over-the-air test coverage in the format on [Raleigh, North
Carolina](/wiki/Raleigh,_North_Carolina "Raleigh, North Carolina") NBC
affiliate [WRAL-EX](/wiki/WRAL-TV "WRAL-TV") (an experimental station using
the future [ATSC 3.0](/wiki/ATSC_3.0 "ATSC 3.0") standard), as well as
[DirecTV](/wiki/DirecTV "DirecTV") and [Dish Network](/wiki/Dish_Network "Dish
Network").[87][88][89]

Also, the Games showcased a [5G](/wiki/5G "5G") mobile communications proof-
of-concept using technology from [Intel](/wiki/Intel "Intel") and
[Nokia](/wiki/Nokia "Nokia") and a national telecommunications firm, [SK
Telecom](/wiki/SK_Telecom "SK Telecom").[90]

##
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Marketing")]

###
Branding[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Branding")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Gold_medal_of_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_in_in_Pyeongchang.jpg/220px-
Gold_medal_of_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_in_in_Pyeongchang.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gold_medal_of_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_in_in_Pyeongchang.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gold_medal_of_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_in_in_Pyeongchang.jpg
"Enlarge")

Gold medal of the 2018 Olympics

The emblem for the Games was unveiled on 3 May 2013. It is a stylized
representation of the [hangul](/wiki/Hangul "Hangul") letters
[ㅍ](/wiki/%E3%85%8D "ㅍ") _p_ and [ㅊ](/wiki/%E3%85%8A "ㅊ") _ch_ , being the
initial sounds of 평창 _Pyeongchang_. The left symbol is said to represent the
[Korean philosophical](/wiki/Korean_philosophy "Korean philosophy") triad of
heaven, earth and humanity ([Korean](/wiki/Korean_language "Korean language"):
천지인 _cheon-ji-in_), and the right symbol a crystal of ice.[91] In the emblem
and all official materials, Pyeongchang was stylized in
[CamelCase](/wiki/CamelCase "CamelCase") as "PyeongChang", in order to
alleviate potential confusion with [Pyongyang](/wiki/Pyongyang
"Pyongyang")—the similarly-named capital of neighbouring [North
Korea](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea").[92]

###
Mascots[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Mascots")]

Main article: [Soohorang and Bandabi](/wiki/Soohorang_and_Bandabi "Soohorang
and Bandabi")

The official mascots for the Games, Soohorang (수호랑), a [white
tiger](/wiki/White_tiger "White tiger"), and Bandabi (반다비), an [Asiatic black
bear](/wiki/Asiatic_black_bear "Asiatic black bear"), were unveiled on 2 June
2016.[93][94]

### Video
games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Video games")]

In June 2017, [Ubisoft](/wiki/Ubisoft "Ubisoft") announced that it would
release an expansion pack for its winter sports video game
_[Steep](/wiki/Steep_\(video_game\) "Steep \(video game\)")_ entitled _Road to
the Olympics_ , which features new game modes and content inspired by the 2018
Winter Olympics.[95][96]

In November 2017, the IOC announced it would support and sponsor an [Intel
Extreme Masters](/wiki/Intel_Extreme_Masters "Intel Extreme Masters")
_[StarCraft II](/wiki/StarCraft_II "StarCraft II")_ tournament in Pyeongchang
preceding the Games. Its support of the tournament as a _de facto_
[demonstration event](/wiki/Demonstration_event "Demonstration event") came on
the heels of a report by the IOC which recognized that [eSports](/wiki/ESports
"ESports") "[could be considered as a sporting
activity](/wiki/Recognition_of_eSports_as_a_form_of_legitimate_sports
"Recognition of eSports as a form of legitimate sports")".[97][98][99] The
tournament was won by [Sasha "Scarlett"
Hostyn](/wiki/Scarlett_\(StarCraft_II_player\) "Scarlett \(StarCraft II
player\)") of Canada; she became the second North American pro to place first
at a major _StarCraft II_ tournament in South Korea, and the first woman to
win a major tournament.[100][101]

## Concerns and
controversies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Concerns and controversies")]

Main article: [Concerns and controversies at the 2018 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/Concerns_and_controversies_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics
"Concerns and controversies at the 2018 Winter Olympics")

### North Korean
relations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: North Korean relations")]

See also: [North Korea–South Korea
relations](/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations "North Korea–South
Korea relations") and [North Korea at the 2018 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/North_Korea_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "North Korea at the
2018 Winter Olympics")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Protesters_criticizing_Moon_Jae-
in_at_Gwanghwamun_Plaza.jpg/200px-Protesters_criticizing_Moon_Jae-
in_at_Gwanghwamun_Plaza.jpg)](/wiki/File:Protesters_criticizing_Moon_Jae-
in_at_Gwanghwamun_Plaza.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Protesters_criticizing_Moon_Jae-in_at_Gwanghwamun_Plaza.jpg
"Enlarge")

Protesters at [Gwanghwamun Plaza](/wiki/Gwanghwamun_Plaza "Gwanghwamun Plaza")
criticizing the game's pro-North Korean measures, calling it the "Pyongyang
Olympics"

Due to the state of relations between [North](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea")
and South Korea, concerns were raised over the security of the 2018 Winter
Olympics, especially in the wake of tensions over North Korean [missile and
nuclear tests](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_North_Korea_crisis "2017–18 North Korea
crisis"). On 20 September 2017, South Korean president [Moon Jae-
in](/wiki/Moon_Jae-in "Moon Jae-in") stated that the country would ensure the
security of the Games.[102] The next day, [Laura Flessel-
Colovic](/wiki/Laura_Flessel-Colovic "Laura Flessel-Colovic"), the French
[Minister of Youth Affairs and
Sports](/wiki/Minister_of_Youth_Affairs_and_Sports_\(France\) "Minister of
Youth Affairs and Sports \(France\)"), stated that France would pull out of
the Games if the safety of its delegation could not be guaranteed.[103]

The next day, Austria and Germany raised similar concerns and also threatened
to skip the Games. France later reaffirmed its participation.[104] In early
December 2017, the [United States Ambassador to the United
Nations](/wiki/United_States_Ambassador_to_the_United_Nations "United States
Ambassador to the United Nations"), [Nikki Haley](/wiki/Nikki_Haley "Nikki
Haley"), told [Fox News](/wiki/Fox_News "Fox News") that it was an "open
question" whether the United States was going to participate in the games,
citing security concerns in the region.[105] However, days later the [White
House Press Secretary](/wiki/White_House_Press_Secretary "White House Press
Secretary"), [Sarah Huckabee Sanders](/wiki/Sarah_Huckabee_Sanders "Sarah
Huckabee Sanders"), stated that the United States would participate.[106]

In his New Year's address on 1 January 2018, North Korean leader [Kim Jong-
un](/wiki/Kim_Jong-un "Kim Jong-un") proposed talks in Seoul over the
country's participation in the Games, which would be the first high-level
talks between the North and South in over two years. Because of the talks,
held on 9 January, North Korea agreed to field athletes in
Pyeongchang.[107][108] On 17 January 2018, it was announced that North and
South Korea had agreed to field a [unified](/wiki/Korea_Team "Korea Team")
[Korean women's ice hockey
team](/wiki/Korea_women%27s_national_ice_hockey_team "Korea women's national
ice hockey team") at the Games, and to enter together under a [Korean
Unification Flag](/wiki/Korean_Unification_Flag "Korean Unification Flag")
during the opening ceremony.[109][110]

These moves were met with opposition in South Korea, including protests and
online petitions; critics argued that the government was attempting to use the
Olympics to spread pro-North Korean sentiment, and that the unified hockey
team would fail.[111] A [rap](/wiki/Rap_music "Rap music") video entitled "The
Regret for Pyeongchang" (평창유감), which echoed this criticism and called the
event the "[Pyongyang](/wiki/Pyongyang "Pyongyang") Olympics", went
[viral](/wiki/Viral_video "Viral video") in the country.[112] Japan's [foreign
affairs minister](/wiki/Minister_for_Foreign_Affairs_\(Japan\) "Minister for
Foreign Affairs \(Japan\)") [Tarō Kōno](/wiki/Tar%C5%8D_K%C5%8Dno "Tarō Kōno")
warned South Korea to be wary of North Korea's "[charm
offensive](/wiki/Charm_offensive "Charm offensive")", and not to ease its
pressure on the country.[109][113]

The South Korean President, [Moon Jae-in](/wiki/Moon_Jae-in "Moon Jae-in"), at
the start of the Olympics shook hands with the sister of North Korean leader
[Kim Jong-un](/wiki/Kim_Jong-un "Kim Jong-un") and a prominent figure of the
regime, [Kim Yo-jong](/wiki/Kim_Yo-jong "Kim Yo-jong"). This marked the first
time since the [Korean War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War") that a member of
the ruling [Kim dynasty](/wiki/Kim_dynasty_\(North_Korea\) "Kim dynasty
\(North Korea\)") had visited South Korea.[114][115] In contrast, US Vice
President [Mike Pence](/wiki/Mike_Pence "Mike Pence") met North Korean
defectors in PyeongChang joined by Fred Warmbier, whose son
[Otto](/wiki/Otto_Warmbier "Otto Warmbier") died the year before after being
released from North Korean captivity.[116] American officials said that North
Korea cancelled a meeting with Pence at the last minute.[117]

The apparent softening of relations between the two countries was marred by
North Korea dispatching general [Kim Yong-chol](/wiki/Kim_Yong-chol "Kim Yong-
chol") to head the North Korean delegation present at the closing ceremony.
The arrival of Kim, held responsible by South Korea for the deaths of dozens
of South Korean navy personnel, was met with 'hostility' but the government
did not oppose his presence at the Olympics. The general ended up being seated
in the same stand as the daughter of the president of the USA, Ivanka
Trump.[118]

### Russian
doping[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Russian doping")]

Main articles: [Doping in Russia](/wiki/Doping_in_Russia "Doping in Russia"),
[McLaren Report](/wiki/McLaren_Report "McLaren Report"), [Oswald
Commission](/wiki/Oswald_Commission "Oswald Commission"), [Russia at the 2014
Winter Olympics § Doping scandal after
Olympics](/wiki/Russia_at_the_2014_Winter_Olympics#Doping_scandal_after_Olympics
"Russia at the 2014 Winter Olympics"), [Russia at the 2016 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/Russia_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics "Russia at the 2016 Summer
Olympics"), and [Olympic Athletes from Russia at the 2018 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/Olympic_Athletes_from_Russia_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics
"Olympic Athletes from Russia at the 2018 Winter Olympics")

####
Participation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Participation")]

[Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia")'s participation in the Winter Olympics was
affected by the aftermath of its [state-sponsored doping
program](/wiki/Russian_doping_scandal "Russian doping scandal"). As a result
the [International Olympic Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee
"International Olympic Committee") suspended the [Russian Olympic
Committee](/wiki/Russian_Olympic_Committee "Russian Olympic Committee").
Russian athletes [whitelisted](/wiki/Whitelist "Whitelist") by the IOC were
allowed to compete
[neutrally](/wiki/Olympic_Athletes_from_Russia_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics
"Olympic Athletes from Russia at the 2018 Winter Olympics") in Pyeongchang,
but they were not allowed to compete under the Russian flag.

#### Official
sanctions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Official sanctions")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Olympic_Athlete_from_Russia_logo_2018.svg/170px-
Olympic_Athlete_from_Russia_logo_2018.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Olympic_Athlete_from_Russia_logo_2018.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Olympic_Athlete_from_Russia_logo_2018.svg "Enlarge")

Approved OAR logo

On 5 December 2017, the IOC announced that the Russian Olympic Committee had
been suspended from the 2018 Winter Olympics with immediate effect. Athletes
who had no previous drug violations and a consistent history of drug testing
were to be allowed to compete under the [Olympic Flag](/wiki/Olympic_Flag
"Olympic Flag") as an [Olympic Athlete from
Russia](/wiki/Olympic_Athletes_from_Russia_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics
"Olympic Athletes from Russia at the 2018 Winter Olympics") (OAR).[119] Under
the terms of the decree, Russian government officials were barred from the
Games, and neither the country's flag nor anthem would be present. The Olympic
Flag and [Olympic Anthem](/wiki/Olympic_Anthem "Olympic Anthem") were
scheduled to be used instead, and on 20 December 2017 the IOC proposed an
alternative logo for the uniforms (shown on right).[120] IOC President [Thomas
Bach](/wiki/Thomas_Bach "Thomas Bach") said that "after following due process
[the IOC] has issued proportional sanctions for this systematic manipulation
while protecting the clean athletes".[121]

By early January 2018, the [IOC](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee
"International Olympic Committee") had sanctioned 43 Russian athletes from the
[2014 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics "2014 Winter Olympics") and
banned them from competing in the 2018 edition and all other future Olympic
Games as part of the [Oswald Commission](/wiki/Oswald_Commission "Oswald
Commission"). All but one of these athletes appealed against their bans to the
[Court of Arbitration for Sport](/wiki/Court_of_Arbitration_for_Sport "Court
of Arbitration for Sport"). The court overturned the sanctions on 28 athletes
meaning that their Sochi medals and results were reinstated but decided that
there was sufficient evidence against 11 athletes to uphold their Sochi
sanctions. The IOC said in a statement that "the result of the CAS decision
does not mean that athletes from the group of 28 will be invited to the Games.
Not being sanctioned does not automatically confer the privilege of an
invitation" and that "this [case] may have a serious impact on the future
fight against doping". The IOC said "that the CAS decision does not mean that
these 28 athletes are innocent" and that they would consider an appeal against
the court's decision. The court also decided that none of the 39 athletes
should be banned from all future Olympic Games, but only the 2018 Games. Three
Russian athletes are still waiting for their hearing which is scheduled to be
conducted after the 2018 Games.[122] After the partially successful appeal, 47
Russian athletes and coaches again appealed to the CAS trying to secure an
invitation to the Games. The appeal was dismissed on 9 February 2018, the day
of the opening ceremony, which was a welcome decision for the IOC.[123]

An original pool of 500 Russian athletes were put forward for consideration
for the Games and 111 were immediately removed from consideration. The
remaining athletes were required to meet pre-games conditions such as further
pre-games tests and reanalysis from stored samples. The athletes would be
considered for invitation to the Games only if these requirements were met.
None of the athletes who had been sanctioned by the Oswald Commission were
still in the pool.[124] The final number of neutral Russian athletes invited
to compete was 169.[125] However, speed skater [Olga Graf](/wiki/Olga_Graf
"Olga Graf") chose not to compete stating that "the sport has become a
bargaining chip in dirty political games".[126] This meant that the final
number of neutral Russians competing at the Games was reduced to 168.

During the games, two Russian athletes out of the 168 who competed failed
doping tests and were disqualified: curler [Aleksandr
Krushelnitckii](/wiki/Aleksandr_Krushelnitckii "Aleksandr Krushelnitckii") who
won a bronze medal in the mixed doubles event; and bob-sledder [Nadezhda
Sergeeva](/wiki/Nadezhda_Sergeeva "Nadezhda Sergeeva") who finished 12th in
the two-woman event.[127][128] The IOC expressed their disappointment at the
positive doping tests and stated that the Olympic Athletes from Russia team
would consequently not be allowed to parade under the Russian flag at the
closing ceremony.[129]

On 28 February 2018 the IOC announced that it had chosen to reinstate Russia's
Olympic membership, just days after the end of the Winter Games. The surprise
decision provoked anger among the international sporting community.[130] The
IOC had planned to reinstate Russia after the Games provided there were no
more failed tests. Their statement read "The suspension of the Russian Olympic
Committee is automatically lifted with immediate effect."[131]

#### Reaction in
Russia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: Reaction in Russia")]

In the past, [Vladimir Putin](/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin"), the
[President of Russia](/wiki/President_of_Russia "President of Russia"), and
other officials had said that it would be a humiliation for Russia if its
athletes were not allowed to compete under the Russian flag.[132] However, his
spokesman later said that no boycott had been discussed.[119] After the IOC
decision was announced, [Ramzan Kadyrov](/wiki/Ramzan_Kadyrov "Ramzan
Kadyrov"), the [Head](/wiki/Head_of_the_Chechen_Republic "Head of the Chechen
Republic") of [Chechnya](/wiki/Chechnya "Chechnya"), announced that no
[Chechen](/wiki/Chechens "Chechens") athletes would participate under a
neutral flag.[133] On 6 December, Putin stated that the Russian government
would not prevent any athletes from participating at the Games as individuals,
but there were calls from other politicians for a boycott.[134][135] [Gennady
Zyuganov](/wiki/Gennady_Zyuganov "Gennady Zyuganov"), a leader of the
[Communist Party of the Russian
Federation](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Russian_Federation "Communist Party
of the Russian Federation"), proposed to send fans with a Soviet [Victory
Banner](/wiki/Victory_Banner "Victory Banner").[136] Russian [Minister of
Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Minister_of_Foreign_Affairs_\(Russia\) "Minister of
Foreign Affairs \(Russia\)") [Sergey Lavrov](/wiki/Sergey_Lavrov "Sergey
Lavrov") has said that the United States "fears honest competition",[137]
affirming Vladimir Putin's position who had said that the United States used
its influence within the [International Olympic
Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic
Committee") to "orchestrate the doping scandal".[138] According to
_[Komsomolskaya Pravda](/wiki/Komsomolskaya_Pravda "Komsomolskaya Pravda")_ ,
a popular Russian newspaper, 86% of the Russian population oppose
participating in the Olympics under a neutral flag.[139]

Despite the OAR designation, many Russian fans still attended the Games,
wearing the Russian colours and chanting "Russia!" in unison, in an act of
defiance against the ban.[140]

#### Reactions in Western
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Reactions in Western media")]

The IOC's decision was criticized by Jack Robertson, primary investigator of
the Russian doping program on behalf of the [World Anti-Doping
Agency](/wiki/World_Anti-Doping_Agency "World Anti-Doping Agency"), who said
that the IOC has issued "a non-punitive punishment meant to save face while
protecting the [IOC's] and Russia's commercial and political interests". He
also emphasized that Russian whistleblowers provided empirical evidence that
"99 percent of [their] national-level teammates were doping". According to
Robertson, "[WADA] has discovered that when a Russian athlete [reaches] the
national level, he or she [has] no choice in the matter: [it is] either dope,
or you're done". "There is currently no intelligence I have seen or heard
about that indicates the state-sponsored doping program has ceased", he
added.[141] It was also reported that Russian officials intensively lobbied US
politicians in an apparent attempt to achieve [Grigory
Rodchenkov's](/wiki/Grigory_Rodchenkov "Grigory Rodchenkov") (main
whistleblower) extradition to Russia.[142]

Justin Peters of [_Slate_ magazine](/wiki/Slate_\(magazine\) "Slate
\(magazine\)") wrote that the IOC "ended up with a situation that seemed to
negate the entire point of the sanctions against Russia. The IOC did not want
there to be a Russian Olympic team at the Pyeongchang Games. And yet the
hockey, curling, and figure-skating arenas are full of teams of Russian
Olympians ... [this is] a half-hearted wrist slap issued by an entity that
appears more interested in saving face than in protecting athletes".[143]

CAS decision to overturn life bans of 28 Russian athletes and restore their
medals met fierce criticism among Olympic officials, including [IOC
president](/wiki/President_of_the_International_Olympic_Committee "President
of the International Olympic Committee") [Thomas Bach](/wiki/Thomas_Bach
"Thomas Bach") who had said this decision is "extremely disappointing and
surprising". [Grigory Rodchenkov](/wiki/Grigory_Rodchenkov "Grigory
Rodchenkov")'s lawyer has said that "the CAS decision would allow doped
athletes to escape without punishment".[144] "[CAS decision] provides yet
another ill-gotten gain for the corrupt Russian doping system generally, and
Putin specifically", he added.[145]
